byline.contributor: Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Jonathan Martin contributed reporting.
byline.original: By STEVE EDER and DAVE PHILIPPS

abstract: Sen Bernie Sanders, during his tenure as chairman of Senate Veterans Affairs Committee, initially doubted reports of dysfunction at Veterans Affairs Dept and its hospitals, dismissing allegations as conservative effort to weaken institution; Sanders eventually changed course and his role in bringing about reforms at department is one of his strongest credentials; however, his initial disbelief points to momentary blindness stemming from deep faith in government.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders initially regarded complaints of trouble at the Department of Veterans Affairs as a play by conservatives to weaken one of the country’s largest social welfare institutions.

headline.main: Faith in Agency Clouded Bernie Sanders’s V.A. Response
headline.print_headline: Sanders Was Slow to Accept V.A. Problems

snippet: Senator Bernie Sanders initially regarded complaints of trouble at the Department of Veterans Affairs as a play by conservatives to weaken one of the country’s largest social welfare institutions.
